this video was rly interesting! as someone with bipolar 2, i have days where i dont sleep when im having hypomanic episodes. currently having one rn and ended up getting to almost stage 4 sleep deprivation. i finally decided to take a shower and sleep yesterday morning. my eyes were red and my face felt like it was inflamed and puffy. when i showered i experienced depersonalization and i was getting tactile hallucinations of the ground moving up and down. it was hard for me to sleep because i just wasnt tired. i managed to sleep but only got 9 hours. when i tired to go sleep my head was racing with thoughts. i cant remember what they were, but i know they were crazy absolutely impossible things (i made sure to remember that bc it was very strange). its very interesting to learn what goes on when you dont sleep. but i cant help but wonder why people in hypo manic states can deal with no sleep. the only reason i really slept was because i was having the worse headache of my life 💀 i think i would have stayed awake if it wasnt for that headache

When I was a young adult, I stayed awake for FIVE DAYS (some say six, but I did nap for an hour the first day so I only count five) for science.. to see if you really "go insane." You start to dramatically slip into insanity at three days, but at five days it is so bad that you realize it. I was hearing voices, seeing hallucinations, and just absolutely emotional. I was on the phone for over an hour, full conversations, but instead of a phone, I was talking to my hand. When I realized it wasn't a phone, I just kept going on with my conversation with a toy phone. It was strange at the moment of experience, terrifying afterwards, but I really did learn so much about the importance of sleep.

Disclaimer: this was totally planned. I had a team of friends keeping an eye on me in case something went sideways. I did this experiment as safely as I possibly could.

CONFUSING!

In 2018 on the first year of my masters (Biological sciences) we discussed this paper about sleep deprivation that really went to extremes (72+ hours I think, may be wrong tho) and its' graphs really show why any amount of deprivation is detrimental for everyday activities.

And it is not only true for huge sleep deprivation for 20-30-40 and more hours, it works similarly (even though for a lesser extent) when you sleep less than usual for a few days in a row.

Now back to my usual dumb self and not a scientist people apparently see in a lab, the most I went without sleep is approximately 40 hours and the next day I couldn't remember half of it, like after being blackout drunk except I didn't drink, and one good long sleep (I'm talking about 12-14 hours of sleep when I normally sleep for 6-7 hours) didn't fix it in a day, it took 3-4 days to get back to normal.

Sleep is way more important than most of us care to think, keep it in mind next time you're awake watching some youtube at 3 am and have to wake up being able to critically think next morning.

After 24  hrs. without sleep a person  may become listless, complain of eyestrain, headaches, seem dazed - termed Brain fog lately, or can be angry. Other symptoms such as fainting, loss of appetite,  and skin ailments may arise  All are not rare and are symptomatic of a challenged immune system. Sleep away illness, eat properly and regularly, and stay calm.     Peace!

This summer I stayed up for 48 hours just to see if I could...

Symptoms I had:
Slight hallucinations
Eyes focusing and unfocusing uncontrollably
Lapses in memory
Sort of out of body experience 😂
Not being able to form coherent sentences
Mood swings

Ways I stayed up:
Coffee coffee coffee
Spraying my face with water
not reading
Not wearing comfy clothes
Drinking lots of water
Eating caffeinated tea leaves (the bag broke open so it wasn’t intentional but it helped)
Exercising
Timed eye breaks (set a timer for like 2 minuted to rest your eyes- enough time for them to recharge but not so much where u fall asleep)

I've gone more than 24 hours awake numerous times - usually along the lines of wake up, do a day's work, come home, do the usual evening stuff, then get wrapped up in reading/writing/whatever and then suddenly realise "Bugger me! I've got to be at work in an hour" (so about 24 hours or so by now), go to work, do a day's work, start really flagging around afternoon tea (it's OK if I keep working but sitting down for 10 minutes, I really start to feel tired) somehow make it through the work day and get myself home, whereupon I stagger to my bed and collapse. Assuming a typical 7am wake-up, 9-to-5 work day and half an hour to walk home, we're looking at 7am on one day to around 5:30pm the following day - about 34.5 hours.
I generally find that part way through the second day, I get a surge - a "second wind" - when I feel fine again, especially if I'm keeping myself busy. Trying to sit still and do nothing I get electric shocks/spasms through my legs - so lunch and (especially) afternoon tea breaks are hellish.
Never lost control of my bladder because of it even I generally spend that 30-odd hours drinking copious amounts of coffee, which is a diuretic (and constitutes additional fluid intake).
I recall that one time I shambled through the door after walking home from work on day two, staggered groggily up the hallway shedding my jacket, reached my bed and pitched forward... and I don't recall hitting the bed, so I'm convinced I lost consciousness somewhere between vertical and horizontal.

I've done an entire week with about 2 hours of sleep a day without any caffeine, and a few months later I did the same thing for four days, but with caffeine at scheduled intervals to keep me alert. The first left me with a constant migrane after day 3, but my cognitive impairment was far more severe in the second case. It was so bad that I could barely get home from my university on the last day (I missed my bus stop AND almost got hit by a car because I kept phasing out of reality) and when people spoke to me I had no idea what on Earth they were saying. Even when I made an effort to pay attention to what was being said to me, it was just beyond me to stay focused and comprehend the awake and alert humans. I also couldn't remember names (this was worse than I can express, I couldn't remember super basic terms by the last day, day 4). When I did this without caffeine, although I did have a significant level of cognitive impairment (and nervous breakdowns haha) it was not nearly as bad even on day 6. I was able to focus better and had a lot more capacity for logic and memory than on day 4 with caffeine.

I have a number of sleep problems and as a result experience an all nighter once or twice a week that I just have to power through as I have to work. As I’ve gotten older, the impact of no sleep has become more noticeable and a lot more akin to being drunk.

The strangest thing, however, is that after a night of no sleep and the following day of work, by the time I get to the evening and bed time, I actually feel more awake and it actually feels challenging to go to sleep, despite being hugely sleep deprived. The whole brain-crashing feeling dissipates and it feels like a second, consecutive all-nighter is doable (although I never attempt it....fortunately at that stage it is still possible to fall asleep eventually unlike the previous night). I don’t recommend trying this to anybody who has no sleep problems though.

I know this goes against every scientific theory, but 3 years into my bachelors biochemistry degree, I routinely pull all nighters (sometimes back to back), and historically I have done better on exams when I stay up late. There is something about a longer period of consciousness that I feel I have gotten to the point where I can confidently take an exam.

It’s not that being well rested has hurt my scores, or that I need to cram studying, but just the slight cloud over everything else seems to allow me to “tunnel” my vision towards a specific subject.

Its insane what not sleeping will do to you! I have to take anxiety meds to ease me to sleep as I have ADHD and OCD. So my thoughts just spin like crazy, but totally out of order like flicking a TV really quick. Plus, I'm 40 now, but since I was 24 I've worked night shift. So I'm in vampire mode all of the time now, although I'm not able to carry a job right now. So I think my record is 4 and a half days awake. Not only did my memory get much much worse, and my appearance suffered REALLY bad, I will slur my speech to the point it sounds like I'm drunk. My senses get really messed up everything smells differently has a different taste, and the words coming from a movie or music overshadow the actual music and the words don't make much sense at all to me. As someone who struggles with insomnia my whole life and I'm also medically nocturnal (hence the insomnia, I've tried to flip my schedule hundreds of times.)
My theory on why people look kinda busted when they're tired is partially a result of the facial muscles.
I notice when I'm sleep deprived my face goes through phases of super relaxed and then I notice my face is tense and sore. So I think you try to force your eyes open, and kinda actively force your face into whatever expression or movement which makes it look very strange and artificial and tense, like in the after pictures show the eyes look almost "reverse squinty" if that makes sense? As if you're fighting to keep them open, which looks unnatural and feels uncanny. Same with any other movements like talking or smiling it looks fake and forced which is unattractive to us.
Then, your face also goes through phases of ultra tired and relaxed and blank like a botox nightmare which also makes people uncomfortable when you seem to be comatose while awake.

That is my theory on why you look less attractive physically, based on appearance and not medical things like paleness or swelling or anything like that.
Idk, I just know I have a lot of experience being sleep deprived and looking angry or aggressive, or so I'm told.

So we've been having this new working hours, like one of them requires us to start working at around 10 pm local time to 5.30 pm the next day.
It's crazy. Yes we get to take a nap in between. But I think it's still inhumane for a company to "force" their workers to work like that. And in which we're not saving lives like doctors or nursers.
So basically we risk our health from the sleep deprived is for nothing else but the company's profit. It's just nonsense.
And yet, as flight attendants we were trained to save people during emergency landing, or taking a quick action anytime someone is in emergency situation like heart attack and such, or handling fire during the flight, sometimes even handling hijackers. Those cases are real.
With being awake for almost 20hr (in some cases even more than 20hr) I am myself unsure if I could perform any of those job effectively since I'm the one who probably needs medical attention.
And we've been making reports for that dreaded schedule, and yet nothing happened.
I really don't know what to do anymore, but really sacrificing my future physical and mental health from all of those sleep deprived isn't worth it when all I'm saving is just the company's profit. It's not like their saving millions of dollars after making a cut on the hotel budget anyway. 🙄

As someone who consistently has really bad sleep patterns (sleeping at 7am, waking at 3pm, then not sleeping until the next day at 5pm etc.) I experience a few things...

1) Burning Eyes, after many hours of being awake past the 16 hour mark whenever I look at the natural light my eyes hurt.

2) I get super inefficient, basically becoming lazy, and find it hard to focus where I zone out a lot, kind of like day dreaming.

3) Find any excuse to get into bed or just lay down. If I know I need to sleep a bit later on I have to force myself to do activities like these guys did, playing video games that are not so strategic but more run and fun, easy to play and not much effort needed.

4) When I eventually do sleep, I sleep for a very long time from like 10-12 hours+

I’ve never actually gone to the doctors about this and it’s been an issue in my life ever since I was younger, I can never keep a sleeping pattern, luckily I am a student at the moment and study from home but I imagine that’s probably why it’s at its worst right now.

I am one of those rare insomniacs who (without tranquilizers) will stay awake for 48 hours without performance deterioration. At the 48 hour mark I start to lose my grip, I can then go an additional 48 hours before losing my touch with reality at which point the world becomes a hassle, to say the least. Things like Ambien, Xanax, Valium, klonopin, clonazalam, etc, don’t put me to sleep but rather I have to take major tranquilizers and am able to sleep a solid 8 hours each night. I’d argue the unattractiveness from sleep deprivation is probably due, at least in part, by dehydration. I read an article on a study  (can’t remember all the details but I’m sure it wouldn’t be hard to find) that found when humans don’t get enough sleep, their bodies have to overcompensate and spends a lot more energy, retaining more water. From what I can remember, when staying up all night, you’re more likely to drink caffeine which can also dehydrate. This dehydration is in part why the day after staying up all night isn’t always the worst part, but actually the next day when you’ve gotten a full nights sleep.

Guys, I presume this 36 hours was while you were eating for quite a number of hours? As you know, eating even moderate carbohydrates and even most proteins will raise blood sugar and insulin, which gives us short-term energy but then a huge crash and tiredness. Have you thought about doing a comparison video about fasting for at least 14 hours (not including sleep time) and then staying up all night and maybe even continuing to fast into the next morning?
As someone who for the health benefits "intermittent fasts" (does not eat or drink any calories) for 16-19 hours most days (though that includes about 7 hours of sleep), I almost always feel very energetic and mentally alert while not eating. That's because my body and brain are now used to burning ketones over glucose. It's only after I start eating high-carb foods that I can get a sudden sugar rush and insulin spike, and then start feeling tired. (To avoid that, when time to start eating, it greatly helps to start with a whey protein drink and then high-fat, low-carb foods -- saving the higher carb foods for evening.) That said, I don't recommend anyone jump into fasting for that long without slowly building up to that level over a period of several weeks or a few months like I did.
But if you are willing to try that, it would be interesting to see how you guys feel while staying awake and not eating, instead of eating. Just be sure to stay hydrated with zero-calorie water or herbal tea (8 oz of black coffee is okay with just one calorie). And in the water or tea, it helps to add electrolytes (pink salt for sodium and cream of tartar for potassium), plus a dash of lemon juice and/or apple cider vinegar (both zero calories) for better pH. And before or when you start eating, also adding a dash of cinnamon helps to control the blood sugar rush from food. If you've already done a video where you tried fasting for a day, I'm sorry if I somehow missed it. Otherwise, would love to hear your thoughts, or anyone else who does time-condensed eating, or wants to try it! :D

I have a very weird sleep pattern that seems to be based on a 26-27 hour day. I generally wake up about 2 hours later every day. After a few days I'll be waking up at midnight, and going to sleep early in the day, for a few days; and sometimes I'll go right back around to a normal cycle of waking up in the morning again..
But, weirdly enough, a lot of the time when I go to sleep in the early evening I'll wake up after 2-3 hours and can't get back to sleep. At this point I usually end up forcing myself to stay awake for ~24-30 hours to get back to a normal human cycle again.
I also find that, a lot of the time when I've been awake for over 17-18 hours, that I'll sleep a lot less that night, instead of more.
When I've been awake for long periods I find that I usually don't want to face other humans, almost like a kind of paranoia where I'm afraid I'll say something stupid, or maybe I just don't want to have to think. Sometimes I'll get hyper for a while and run around cleaning the house, and other times I'll just sit down and not know what to do with myself.

I've NEVER seen anyone who was sleep deprived act drunk or giddy. Not a single time. Being sleep deprived is like having all your energy taken away. You move like a slug through pudding, you can't focus and your speech might be a bit slurred or just become toneless.

Not only that, but the after pics...look like people squinting with mussed hair. No dark rings under your eyes, no vacant stare, no look of exhaustion. You just look like you didn't do any cosmetic touch-ups that morning.

Being sleep deprived doesn't make you giggly and bubbly. It makes you irritable and mostly withdrawn. I've never known anyone to stay up longer than 24 hours and act the way the two of you did.

So, yeah, it feels pretty suspect. Because my life IS sleep deprivation. I regularly go anywhere from 36 to 72 hours without sleep. I've been around people with similar sleep problems. And in 20+ years of both being sleep deprived and being around others who are, I've seen nothing matching hat you recorded here.

It looks an awful lot like people who don't know what sleep deprivation is trying to act like they are. Like someone who never got drunk or high trying to emulate what it feels like.

Real can spot real, gentlemen.

​​@UCC552Sd-3nyi_tk2BudLUzA Actually we do know why we need to sleep (kind of).  Our cells use the circulatory system to ferry fuel to the cells and waste out; but, it can only handle small molecules; so, our body uses the Lymphatic system to carry the larger (slower moving) molecules.  The challenge is the cells in the brain don't have access to the Lymphatic system (or at least we didn't think they did).  In a Scientific American article I ready they found that the brain did have a system similar to the Lymphatic system called the Glyphatic system; but, it was kind of hidden and it only operates when we sleep.  No sleep, not drain.  Sort of like a plug in your septic system, you may not notice it at first; but, if it stays plugged long enough, YOU WILL notice it.
